awd_abstract_narration:
A three-manifold is a space where an object can move around in three distinct perpendicular directions. The universe that we inhabit is a three-manifold whose global structure we do not yet understand. Thanks to powerful theorems by Thurston, Perelman, and Mostow, we do know that the geometry of a manifold (measurements of angles, distances, and curvature) is closely tied to its large-scale structure. What is missing at this point is a quantitative understanding of how geometry and large-scale topology determine one another. This project seeks quantitative information of this nature. It contains suitable sub-projects for graduate students. 

More specifically, this project seeks to make progress on several fundamental questions involving the geometry of negatively curved three-manifolds and their fundamental groups. One question involves quantitative control on the change in geometry under Dehn surgery, including applications to the cosmetic surgery conjecture. A second question involves understanding Kleinian groups in which two independent elements move a point by a small distance, with applications to bounding the Margulis constant. A third question involves a quantitative understanding of the way in which three-manifold groups act on CAT(0) cube complexes, with an eye toward developing tools for the Cannon conjecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerned the structure of 3-dimensional manifolds. These are spaces where an object such as a helicopter can fly around in 3 different perpendicular directions. A local neighborhood in a 3-manifold looks just like a neighborhood of the Earth, or like the solar system. However, the global structure of a 3-manifold can be quite elaborate, featuring many different ways to fly off in one direction and come back from another. In other words, 3-manifolds are models for our physical universe. A mathematical understanding of these models gives tools for understanding the physical universe itself.

One major theme of this project is the interplay between topology (interconnectedness) and geometry (measurements of angles, lengths, and curvature). For universes with negative curvature, which are traditionally the least understood, some of the results developed under this project provide very precise estimates on geometry, including a clear understanding of how lengths change under surgical operations. One collaboration supported by this project involves ongoing work to determine the transition between tightly-wound "thin regions" and spacious "thick regions" in a manifold. This should also enhance our mathematical and physical understanding. Finally, this project has led to some new results about the symmetry of manifolds and provided new ways to unwrap them into larger manifolds with powerful features. This sub-project should contribute to the areas of geometry, topology, and group theory.
